articles.headline: 53 Tons of Rotting Pork and Other Brexit Nightmares
articles.snippet: With Britain out of the European Union, companies that trade with the continent are contending with expensive disruptions to their businesses and a plunge in exports.
articles.abstract: With Britain out of the European Union, companies that trade with the continent are contending with expensive disruptions to their businesses and a plunge in exports.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As the new year made Brexit a reality, Tony Hale encountered the pitfalls of Europe’s redrawn geography. Specifically, he confronted the need to extricate 53 tons of rotting pork products from administrative purgatory at a port in the Netherlands.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman, Stephen Castle and Eshe Nelson

articles.headline: Trump’s Lawyers Deny He Incited Capitol Mob, Saying It’s Democrats Who Spur Violence
articles.snippet: The former president’s legal team rested its case without using even a quarter of the 16 hours allotted to it.
articles.abstract: The former president’s legal team rested its case without using even a quarter of the 16 hours allotted to it.
articles.lead_paragraph: Former President Donald J. Trump’s legal team mounted a combative defense on Friday focused more on assailing Democrats for “hypocrisy” and “hatred” than justifying Mr. Trump’s own monthslong effort to overturn a democratic election that culminated in last month’s deadly assault on the Capitol.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: For the Defense: Twisted Facts and Other Staples of the Trump Playbook
articles.snippet: The lawyers representing the former president in his impeachment trial are the latest in a rotating cast that has always had trouble satisfying a mercurial and headstrong client.
articles.abstract: The lawyers representing the former president in his impeachment trial are the latest in a rotating cast that has always had trouble satisfying a mercurial and headstrong client.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since Donald J. Trump began his run for president, he has been surrounded by an ever-shifting cast of lawyers with varying  abilities to control, channel and satisfy their mercurial and headstrong client.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Inside a Nursing Home After the Vaccine: Joy, Relief and Game Night
articles.snippet: A nursing home where vaccinations have finished offers a glimpse at what the other side of the pandemic might look like.
articles.abstract: A nursing home where vaccinations have finished offers a glimpse at what the other side of the pandemic might look like.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEELING, W.Va. — The day had finally arrived.
articles.byline: By Sarah Mervosh and Amr Alfiky

articles.headline: Silicon Valley’s Safe Space
articles.snippet: Slate Star Codex was a window into the psyche of many tech leaders building our collective future. Then it disappeared.
articles.abstract: Slate Star Codex was a window into the psyche of many tech leaders building our collective future. Then it disappeared.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.

articles.headline: With Mardi Gras Parades Canceled, Floats Find a New Home
articles.snippet: Mr. Pierre’s team installed floats, including one dedicated to Dolly Parton.
articles.abstract: Mr. Pierre’s team installed floats, including one dedicated to Dolly Parton.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — The sunset streamed through the warehouse windows where René Píerre carved float props out of Styrofoam, carefully adding details to dozens of decorations for this year’s Mardi Gras celebration on Tuesday.
articles.byline: By Annie Flanagan and Akasha Rabut

articles.headline: Trump Acquitted of Inciting Insurrection, Even as Bipartisan Majority Votes ‘Guilty’
articles.snippet: The verdict was unlikely to be the final word for former President Donald J. Trump, his badly divided party or the festering wounds the Jan. 6 riot that prompted the impeachment left behind.
articles.abstract: The verdict was unlikely to be the final word for former President Donald J. Trump, his badly divided party or the festering wounds the Jan. 6 riot that prompted the impeachment left behind.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A Senate still bruised from the most violent attack on the Capitol in two centuries acquitted former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday in his second impeachment trial, as all but a few Republicans locked arms to reject a case that he incited the Jan. 6 rampage in a last-ditch attempt to cling to power.

articles.headline: One Legacy of Impeachment: The Most Complete Account So Far of Jan. 6
articles.snippet: Yet for all the heart-pounding narrative of that day presented on the Senate floor, what was also striking was how many questions remained unanswered.
articles.abstract: Yet for all the heart-pounding narrative of that day presented on the Senate floor, what was also striking was how many questions remained unanswered.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pure savagery of the mob that rampaged through the Capitol that day was breathtaking, as cataloged by the injuries inflicted on those who tried to guard the nation’s elected lawmakers. One police officer lost an eye, another the tip of his finger. Still another was shocked so many times with a Taser gun that he had a heart attack.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Republican Acquittal of Trump Is a Pivotal Moment for the Party
articles.snippet: The vote, signaling how thoroughly the party has come to be defined by the personality of one man, is likely to leave a blemish on the historical record.
articles.abstract: The vote, signaling how thoroughly the party has come to be defined by the personality of one man, is likely to leave a blemish on the historical record.
articles.lead_paragraph: During the first trial of Donald J. Trump, 13 months ago, the former president commanded near-total fealty from his party. His conservative defenders were ardent and numerous, and Republican votes to convict him — for pressuring Ukraine to help him smear Joseph R. Biden Jr. — were virtually nonexistent.

articles.headline: A Year of Hardship, Helped and Hindered by Washington
articles.snippet: For Kathryn Stewart, a struggling single mother in Michigan, the past year showed how much safety net programs can help — and how the nation’s fickleness about them can add confusion and uncertainty to fear and worry.
articles.abstract: For Kathryn Stewart, a struggling single mother in Michigan, the past year showed how much safety net programs can help — and how the nation’s fickleness about them can add confusion and uncertainty to fear and worry.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the coronavirus pandemic struck last March, Kathryn Stewart was working at a gas station in rural Michigan and living in her mother’s trailer with eight relatives, three dogs and a budget with no room for error. Her mother, who is disabled, soon urged her to quit to avoid bringing home the disease. Ms. Stewart reluctantly agreed, wondering how she would support herself and her 10-year-old son.

articles.headline: Big Tech’s Unlikely Next Battleground: North Dakota
articles.snippet: A vote on a bill this week is part of a movement that could cost Apple and Google billions of dollars. State legislatures are becoming the fight’s new front.
articles.abstract: A vote on a bill this week is part of a movement that could cost Apple and Google billions of dollars. State legislatures are becoming the fight’s new front.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, a lobbyist approached Kyle Davison, a North Dakota state senator, with an unusual proposal: a law to stop Apple and Google from forcing companies in the state to hand over a share of their app sales.

articles.headline: W.T.O. Set to Gain New Chief, but Deep Issues Remain
articles.snippet: The appointment of the Nigerian economist Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala to lead the World Trade Organization removes one obstacle, but the group’s future remains uncertain.
articles.abstract: The appointment of the Nigerian economist Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala to lead the World Trade Organization removes one obstacle, but the group’s future remains uncertain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Ngozi Okonjo-Iweala, a Nigerian economist and former finance minister, is poised to become the first woman and first African to lead the World Trade Organization, when the members of the global trade body meet on Monday to consider her candidacy for director general.

articles.headline: How a Minimum-Wage Increase Is Being Felt in a Low-Wage City
articles.snippet: Is $15 an hour too much, or not enough? Fresno, Calif., may be a laboratory for a debate over the minimum wage that is heating up on the national level.
articles.abstract: Is $15 an hour too much, or not enough? Fresno, Calif., may be a laboratory for a debate over the minimum wage that is heating up on the national level.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even before the pandemic, Elsa Rodriguez Killion realized that Casa Corona, her restaurant in Fresno, Calif., was going to have to change with the times.

articles.headline: Postcard From Peru: Why the Morality Plays Inside The Times Won’t Stop
articles.snippet: Other news organizations have their own personnel dramas. But none attract the spotlight the way The Times does.
articles.abstract: Other news organizations have their own personnel dramas. But none attract the spotlight the way The Times does.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2012, when The New York Times was panicked about its financial future, this newspaper went into the travel business. It began selling “Times Journeys,” on which an expert beat reporter would be your guide to Berlin or the Galápagos Islands.

articles.headline: Why Seven Republican Senators Voted to Convict Trump
articles.snippet: The Republicans who broke with their party to find Donald J. Trump guilty were an eclectic group, bound by their shared lack of concern about retribution from the former president or his followers.
articles.abstract: The Republicans who broke with their party to find Donald J. Trump guilty were an eclectic group, bound by their shared lack of concern about retribution from the former president or his followers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The seed for Senator Bill Cassidy’s decision to find Donald J. Trump guilty of inciting an insurrection was planted one day last fall, when he received an email from a friend that was full of the then-president’s false claims about a stolen election.

articles.headline: Biden Takes Center Stage With Ambitious Agenda as Trump’s Trial Ends
articles.snippet: The president plans to quickly press for his $1.9 trillion stimulus bill, and then move on to infrastructure, immigration, climate change and other major priorities.
articles.abstract: The president plans to quickly press for his $1.9 trillion stimulus bill, and then move on to infrastructure, immigration, climate change and other major priorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Biden’s allies say that with the distraction of the impeachment trial of his predecessor now over, he will quickly press for passage of his $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief plan before moving on to an even bigger agenda in Congress that includes infrastructure, immigration, criminal justice reform, climate change and health care.

articles.headline: The Taliban Close In on Afghan Cities, Pushing the Country to the Brink
articles.snippet: The Taliban have positioned themselves around several major population centers, including the capital of Kandahar Province, as the Biden administration weighs whether to withdraw or to stay.
articles.abstract: The Taliban have positioned themselves around several major population centers, including the capital of Kandahar Province, as the Biden administration weighs whether to withdraw or to stay.
articles.lead_paragraph: PANJWAI, Afghanistan — The Taliban have been encroaching on key cities around Afghanistan for months, threatening to drive the country to its breaking point and push the Biden administration into a no-win situation just as the United States’ longest war is supposed to be coming to an end.
articles.byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Taimoor Shah and Jim Huylebroek

articles.headline: Pennsylvania G.O.P.’s Push for More Power Over Judiciary Raises Alarms
articles.snippet: After fighting the election results, state Republicans are trying to increase their control of the courts. Outraged Democrats and good government groups see it as a new kind of gerrymandering.
articles.abstract: After fighting the election results, state Republicans are trying to increase their control of the courts. Outraged Democrats and good government groups see it as a new kind of gerrymandering.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the Pennsylvania Supreme Court unanimously rejected a Republican attempt to overturn the state’s election results in November, Justice David N. Wecht issued his own pointed rebuke, condemning the G.O.P. effort as “futile” and “a dangerous game.”

articles.headline: Clubhouse, a Tiny Audio Chat App, Breaks Through
articles.snippet: The 11-month-old app has exploded in popularity, even as it grapples with harassment, misinformation and privacy issues.
articles.abstract: The 11-month-old app has exploded in popularity, even as it grapples with harassment, misinformation and privacy issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and Taylor Lorenz
